title: Lavender Tallow Balm: What Actually Happened to My Winter Skin
body:
Okay so. My skin in winter is a whole thing. It’s not just dry. It’s like, angry dry. Tight, itchy, sometimes red patches show up near my jawline for no reason. Feels like paper. I’d wake up and it was already tight. I tried a lot of stuff. That fancy blue jar from the department store, the one everyone talks about. Made my face feel weirdly hot. Tried the drugstore gel creams. They’d sit on top, feel okay for an hour, then vanish. My skin just drank it and was still thirsty. I was spending a fortune on these little bottles and nothing was fixing the actual problem. It was just putting on a temporary wet t-shirt, you know? So I got desperate. And I kept seeing this beef tallow stuff. For your face. Sounded insane. Like, cooking fat? On my skin? I pictured smelling like a burger. But my hands were cracking, my face hurt, and I was out of ideas. So I ordered this whipped tallow balm, the lavender one. From some small shop on Etsy. Figured it was a last-ditch thing. My phone was at like 12% when I checked out. Whatever.

## How I Started Using Beef Tallow on My Face

The jar showed up maybe a week later. Small. Simple. I opened it. Texture was weird. Not bad weird. Thick. Like really thick. But not greasy? You scoop a tiny bit and it’s solid, then it melts the second it touches your skin. That part was cool. Smelled like lavender. But not like a candle or air freshener. More like… the actual plant. Like if you crushed the flowers. A little earthy underneath. Not sweet. I was sitting on my couch, heat blasting, skin feeling tight, and just went for it. After I washed my face at night. I used maybe the size of a pea for my whole face. Rubbed my palms together first. It warmed up instantly. Then just pressed it in. Didn’t rub hard. Just pressed. And it was gone. Like, absorbed. My face didn’t look shiny. It felt… quiet. That’s the only word. The tightness was just gone. Not covered up. Gone. I didn’t expect that. I thought it’d be a greasy mess. I went to bed thinking, well, I’ll probably wake up with a new pimple. But I didn’t.

## Why This Tallow Balm for Dry Skin Actually Makes Sense

So I looked it up after, because I was confused how it worked so fast. Apparently, tallow from grass-fed cows is structurally really close to our own skin’s sebum. Like, our bodies recognize it. So it doesn’t just sit there—it gets absorbed properly and helps your skin barrier actually repair itself. It’s not just a layer on top. It’s like giving your skin the building blocks it’s missing. Especially in winter when everything is harsh and dry. All those lotions I was using had water as the first ingredient. Water evaporates. Tallow doesn’t. It’s just pure moisture. For someone with skin that’s both dry and kind of sensitive, this made a stupid amount of sense. My skin wasn’t reacting because it knew what this stuff was. It’s a natural moisturizer for skin that’s given up on everything else. I started using it every night. The lavender scent… it’s not strong. But it’s there. It’s calming. It became part of the routine. Wash face, tallow balm, done. Took like 60 seconds.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

The changes were small at first. Then not so small. After a week, no more tight mornings. After two, those red patches by my jaw were just… gone. Not pink. Gone. My skin felt thicker. Not in a bad way. In a resilient way. Like it could handle going outside in the wind. I even started using a tiny dab on my knuckles and elbows. They were sandpaper. Always. Now they’re… fine. Not baby soft, whatever that means. Just normal. Not cracked. It’s the best tallow for that deep, winter dryness that feels like it’s in your bones. I even put a little on a cut I had from a cardboard box. Healed way faster. It’s just good at fixing broken barrier stuff. I told my sister about it. She has psoriasis on her hands sometimes. She was skeptical too. Took her a month to try it. Now she texts me about it. “My hands don’t look like a desert lizard anymore.” High praise.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar. The first one lasted me almost three months, using it every single night. A little goes a seriously long way. It’s become my non-negotiable. When I travel, it comes with me. I used it in a really dry hotel room last month and my skin didn’t even notice the change. That never happens. For me, this is the tallow balm for dry, sensitive skin that actually fixed the problem instead of just talking about it. It’s not magic. It’s just… really good at its one job. Moisturizing. Deeply. Without fuss. No ten-step routine. Just this one thing. If your skin is feeling tight, angry, or just perpetually thirsty no matter what you put on it, this might be worth a shot. Especially in winter. It’s a simple solution to a stupidly annoying problem. I got mine from this little Etsy shop that makes it in small batches. Feels good to use something that’s just… one ingredient, basically. Well, two with the lavender.

Anyway. My skin’s happy. I’m not spending $50 on cream that doesn’t work. That’s the whole story.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. Because it’s so similar to the oils our own skin makes, it absorbs properly and helps repair the skin barrier. It’s not like putting olive oil on your face. It’s more like giving your skin what it’s already trying to produce.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores easy. Since it absorbs and mimics sebum, it doesn’t just sit in your pores like some heavy creams. It’s more like your skin uses it up. But everyone’s different, I guess.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Like real lavender. Not perfume. It’s earthy and herbal, not sweet. It’s calming. Fades pretty quick after you put it on. You’re not walking around smelling like a soap shop.

So yeah. If your skin’s being difficult, might be worth a shot. It just works.
